SEARCH
Module org.klojang.jdbc
Package org.klojang.jdbc

Interface SessionConfig

public interface SessionConfig

SessionConfig objects allow you to fine-tune or modify various aspects of how Klojang JDBC processes and executes SQL. SessionConfig is an interface that provides default implementations for all its methods. The default implementations specify Klojang JDBC's default behaviour. You might want to implement SessionConfig through an anonymous class: 


 SessionConfig config = new SessionConfig() {
   public boolean saveEnumAsString(Class<?> beanType, String enumProperty Class<?> enumType) {
     return true;
   }
 };

Alternatively, you could use the provided "withers" to modify how Klojang JDBC operates: 


 SessionConfig config = SessionConfig.getDefaultConfig().withEnumsSavedAsStrings();

It is recommended that you store SessionConfig objects in public static final fields and share them whenever and wherever possible.

Author:
Ayco Holleman

  • Method Details

    • getDefaultConfig

      static SessionConfig getDefaultConfig()
      Returns a SessionConfig instance which does not override any of the defaults provided by the SessionConfig instance.
      Returns:
      a SessionConfig instance which does not override any of the defaults provided by the SessionConfig instance

    • getCustomBinder

      default CustomBinder getCustomBinder(Class<?> beanType, String propertyName, Class<?> propertyType)
      Returns a CustomBinder for the provided combination of arguments, or null if no CustomBinder is required for the provided combination of arguments. The default implementation returns null. You may ignore any or all arguments that you don't need in order to determine whether to use a CustomBinder.
      Parameters:
      beanType - the type of the JavaBean, record, or Map containing the values for which to specify a CustomBinder
      propertyName - the name of the bean property, record component, or map key for which to specify a CustomBinder
      propertyType - the type of the values for which to specify a CustomBinder
      Returns:
      a CustomBinder for the provided combination of arguments

    • getCustomReader

      default CustomReader getCustomReader(Class<?> beanType, String propertyName, Class<?> propertyType, int sqlType)
      Returns a CustomReader for the provided combination of arguments, or null if no CustomReader is required for the provided combination of arguments. The default implementation returns null. You may ignore any or all arguments that you don't need in order to determine whether to use a CustomReader.
      Parameters:
      beanType - the type of the JavaBean, record, or Map that will receive the value from the ResultSet. Note that when writing to a Map (using a MapExtractor), this argument will always be Map.class irrespective of the exact type of the Map returned by the MapExtractor.
      propertyName - the name of the bean property, record component, or map key that will receive the value from the ResultSet
      propertyType - the type of the values for which to specify a CustomReader. Note that when writing to a Map (using a MapExtractor), this argument will always be Object.class because we don't know the runtime type yet of the values when the MapExtractor is configured, and Java's type erase feature prevents us from being any more specific beforehand.
      sqlType - the SQL datatype of the column for which to specify a CustomReader. Must be one of the constants of the java.sql.Types, like Types.VARCHAR or Types.TIMESTAMP}
      Returns:
      a CustomReader for the provided combination of arguments

    • getSQLType

      default Integer getSQLType(Class<?> beanType, String propertyName, Class<?> propertyType)
      Returns the SQL datatype for the provided combination of arguments, or null if want you leave it to Klojang JDBC to determine the SQL datatype. The default implementation returns null. If not null, the return value must be one of the constants in the java.sql.Types class (like Types.VARCHAR). This method will only be evaluated if getCustomBinder() returned null. You may ignore any or all arguments that you don't need in order to determine the return value. For example, in many cases the type of the value (provided via the propertyType argument) will be all you need to know in order to determine the corresponding SQL datatype.
      Parameters:
      beanType - the type of the JavaBean, record, or Map containing the value
      propertyName - the name of the bean property, record component, or map key for which to specify the SQL datatype.
      propertyType - the type of the value whose SQL datatype to determine
      Returns:
      one of the class constants of the java.sql.Types class or null

    • saveEnumAsString

      default boolean saveEnumAsString(Class<?> beanType, String enumProperty, Class<? extends Enum<?>> enumType)

      Whether to save enums as strings (by calling their toString() method) or as ints (by calling their ordinal() method). The default implementation returns false, meaning that by default Klojang JDBC will save enums as ints. More precisely: enums will be bound using preparedStatement.setInt(paramIndex, myEnum.ordinal()). The target column may still be a VARCHAR column since most databases will easily convert integers to strings when needed. Whichever option you choose, the reverse process — converting ResultSet values to enums — will always work correctly, without requiring additional configuration. You may ignore any or all arguments that you don't need in order to determine the return value. To save all enums in your application as strings, ignore all arguments and simply return true straight away.

      This method will only be evaluated if getSqlType() returned null.

      Parameters:
      beanType - the type of the JavaBean, record, or Map containing the value
      enumProperty - the name of the bean property, record component, or map key for which to specify the SQL datatype
      enumType - the type of the enum value whose SQL datatype to determine
      Returns:
      whether to bind enums as strings (true) or as ints (false)

    • getDateTimeFormatter

      default DateTimeFormatter getDateTimeFormatter(Class<?> beanType, String dateTimeProperty, Class<? extends TemporalAccessor> dateTimeType)
      Returns the DateTimeFormatter to be used for date/time values, or null if the provided combination of arguments does not require the use of a DateTimeFormatter. The default implementation returns null. If a non-null value is returned, date/time objects will be saved as a string rather than as a SQL Types.DATE or Types.TIMESTAMP. More precisely: they will be bound using preparedStatement.setString(paramIndex, formatter.format(value)). The target column may still be a DATE or TIMESTAMP column since most databases will easily convert a (properly formatted) string to a DATE or TIMESTAMP. You may ignore any or all arguments that you don't need in order to determine the return value.

      This method will only be evaluated if getSqlType() returned null.

      Parameters:
      beanType - the type of the JavaBean, record, or Map containing the value
      dateTimeProperty - the name of the bean property, record component, or map key for which to use the DateTimeFormatter
      dateTimeType - the exact date/time type for which to use the DateTimeFormatter
      Returns:
      the DateTimeFormatter to be used for a date/time values, or null if the provided combination of arguments does not require the use of a DateTimeFormatter.

    • getSerializer

      default Function<Object,String> getSerializer(Class<?> beanType, String propertyName, Class<?> propertyType)

      Returns the serialization function to be used for the provided combination of arguments, or null if no special serialization is required for the provided combination of arguments. The default implementation returns null. If a non-null value is returned, objects will be bound using preparedStatement.setString(paramIndex, function.apply(object)). You may ignore any or all arguments that you don't need in order to determine the return value.

      This method can be used to save types for which no default java-to-SQL type mapping exists. If you specify a serializer for such a type, it pays if the type also contains a static factory method that takes a String and returns an instance of that type (in other words, a deserializer). If there is exactly one such method, Klojang JDBC will use it for the reverse process: deserializing ResultSet values into instances of that type. Alternatively, if the type contains a constructor that takes a single String argument, then that constructor will be used as the deserialization mechanism. This works for classes like StringBuilder, but it may be assuming a bit too much for other classes. In that case, specify a CustomReader that will deserialize the values.

      Note that if the type is properly serialized through its toString() method, you don't need to specify a serializer for it. Klojang JDBC will already, as a last resort, call toString() on (non-null) values with an unknown type. More precisely, it will bind them using preparedStatement.setString(paramIndex, value.toString()).

      Parameters:
      beanType - the type of the JavaBean, record, or Map containing the value to be bound
      propertyName - the name of the bean property, record component, or map key for which to specify the serializer function
      propertyType - the type of the value for which to specify the serializer function
      Returns:
      the serialization function to be used for the provided combination of arguments, or null if no special serialization is required for the provided combination of arguments

    • getBinarySerializer

      default Function<Object,byte[]> getBinarySerializer(Class<?> beanType, String propertyName, Class<?> propertyType)

      Returns the serialization function to be used for the provided combination of arguments, or null if no special serialization is required for the provided combination of arguments. The default implementation returns null. If a non-null value is returned, objects will be bound using preparedStatement.setBytes(paramIndex, function.apply(object)). You may ignore any or all arguments that you don't need in order to determine the return value.

      This method can be used to save types for which no default java-to-SQL type mapping exists. If you specify a serializer for such a type, it pays if the type also contains a static factory method that takes a String and returns an instance of that type (in other words, a deserializer). If there is exactly one such method, Klojang JDBC will use it for the reverse process: deserializing ResultSet values into instances of that type. Alternatively, if the type contains a constructor that takes a single byte[] array argument, then that constructor will be used as the deserialization mechanism. That may work for some classes, but it may be assuming a bit too much for other classes. In that case, specify a CustomReader that will deserialize the values.

      Parameters:
      beanType - the type of the JavaBean, record, or Map containing the value to be bound
      propertyName - the name of the bean property, record component, or map key for which to specify the serializer function
      propertyType - the type of the value for which to specify the serializer function
      Returns:
      the serialization function to be used for the provided combination of arguments, or null if no special serialization is required for the provided combination of arguments

    • getPropertyToColumnMapper

      default NameMapper getPropertyToColumnMapper()
      Specifies the NameMapper to be used for mapping bean properties, record components, or map keys to column names. The default implementation returns camelCaseToSnakeUpperCase(), which would map "camelCaseToSnakeUpperCase" to "CAMEL_CASE_TO_SNAKE_UPPER_CASE". (It would also map "WordCase" a.k.a. "PascalCase" to "WORD_CASE" and "PASCAL_CASE", respectively, since all characters end up in upper case anyhow.)
      Returns:
      the NameMapper to be used for mapping bean properties, record components, or map keys to column names

    • getColumnToPropertyMapper

      default NameMapper getColumnToPropertyMapper()
      Specifies the NameMapper to be used for mapping column names to bean properties, record components, or map keys. The default implementation returns snakeCaseToCamelCase(), which would map "SNAKE_CASE_TO_CAMEL_CASE" to "snakeCaseToCamelCase". (It would also map "snake_case_to_camel_case" to "SNAKE_CASE_TO_CAMEL_CASE" because the casing of the input string is irrelevant for this NameMapper.)
      Returns:
      the NameMapper to be used for mapping column names to bean properties, record components, or map keys

    • withPropertyToColumnMapper

      default SessionConfig withPropertyToColumnMapper(NameMapper mapper)
      Returns a new instance that is equal to this instance except with the property-to-column mapper set to the specified NameMapper.
      Parameters:
      mapper - the NameMapper to be used for mapping bean properties, record components, or map keys to column names
      Returns:
      a new instance that is equal to this instance except with the property-to-column mapper set to the specified NameMapper.

    • withColumnToPropertyMapper

      default SessionConfig withColumnToPropertyMapper(NameMapper mapper)
      Returns a new instance that is equal to this instance except with the column-to-property mapper set to the specified NameMapper.
      Parameters:
      mapper - the NameMapper to be used for mapping column names to bean properties, record components, or map keys
      Returns:
      a new instance that is equal to this instance except with the column-to-property mapper set to the specified NameMapper.

    • withNamesMappedAsIs

      default SessionConfig withNamesMappedAsIs()
      Returns a new instance that is equal to this instance except that property names are mapped as-is to column names and vice versa.
      Returns:
      a new instance that is equal to this instance except that property names are mapped as-is to column names and vice versa
      See Also:
      • NameMapper.AS_IS

    • withLowerCaseColumnNames

      default SessionConfig withLowerCaseColumnNames()
      Returns a new instance that is equal to this instance except that property names are mapped to column names using the camelCaseToSnakeLowerCase() name mapper. This NameMapper would map "camelCaseToSnakeLowerCase" to "camel_case_to_snake_lower_case". It would also map "WordCase" a.k.a. "PascalCase" to "word_case" and "pascal_case", respectively, since all characters end up in lower case anyhow. The reverse (column-to-property) mapper remains at its default value (snakeCaseToCamelCase()). When mapping snake case names to camel case names, the casing of the input string is irrelevant.
      Returns:
      a new instance that is equal to this instance except that property names are mapped to column names using the camelCaseToSnakeLowerCase() name mapper

    • withEnumsSavedAsStrings

      default SessionConfig withEnumsSavedAsStrings()
      Returns a new instance that is equal to this instance except that all enums will be saved by calling toString() on them.
      Returns:
      a new instance that is equal to this instance except that all enums will be saved by calling toString() on them.
